description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med Svenska missionsrådet (SMR) om bidrag till humanitära insatser 2014-2016. Beslutet tas i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel paragraf 3.11.3 och avser tredje året av ett treårigt avtal.
SMR har inför 2016 inkommit med en ansökan som presenterar organisationens humanitära arbete 2016. Total ansöker SMR om 41 900 000 SEK från Sida. SMR ansöker om finansiering för arbete 1) i Palestina, Sudan, Sydsudan, Uganda, Niger, Etiopien och Bangladesh, 2) för insatser i form av så kallad RRM (Rapid Response Mechanism) som möjliggör snabbt stöd till nya kriser som kan komma att inträffa under året samt 3) för kapacitetsstärkande aktiviteter för SMRs partners.
Totalt ansöker SMR om 41 900 000 för landinsatser, RRM och ett kapacitetsstärkande projekt, vilket Sida föreslås finansiera. Sida bedömer att arbetet kommer bidra till att möta de behov som identifierats i de humanitära landanalyserna (så kallade HCAs) Sida genomfört inför 2016. SMR planerar att under 2016 arbeta med tre olika teman i sju länder: - Integration av återvändande, där SMR fokuserar på att säkerställa tillgång till vatten och sanitet för befolkningen i områden som har en stor andel återvändande flyktingar. Insatser planeras i Niger, Sydsudan och Sudan. - Humanitära behov i komplexa humanitära kriser, där SMR arbetar med att stärka värdsamhällens kapacitet att möta flyktingars behov och arbeta med konfliktkänslighetsinsatser för att undvika konflikt mellan flyktingar och värdsamhällen. Insats planeras för Niger, Palestina, Etiopien och Uganda - Utsatthet på grund av klimatförändringar, där SMR arbetar med att stärka resiliens på lokalnivå för att minska människors utsatthet och öka deras motståndskraft. Insatser planeras i Bangladesh.
SMR verkar som paraplyorganisation för sina implementerade partners. I ansökan 2014-2016 beskriver SMR vad rollen som paraplyorganisation innebär och hur relaterade kostnader är kalkylerade. SMRs kostnader som paraply täcks av Sidas administrationsbidrag om 7%. 2016 söker SMR 2 251 000 SEK för administrativa kostnader som paraplyorganisation, vilka inkluderar kvalitetssäkring av implementerade partners arbete. Utöver detta söker SMR 2016 om 900 000 SEK för kapacitetsstärkande arbete av partners. Mål och aktiviteter för detta arbete, inklusive resultatramverk och budget finns med i ansökan. Sida bedömer arbetet som relevant och relaterade kostnader som rimliga.
Sida bedömer att insatsen kommer bidra till målen i Strategin för humanitärt bistånd genom Sida 2011- 2014 (förlängd till december 2016).
Slutligen så bedömer Sida att samtliga medel för 2016 ska utbetalas i början av året för att på bästa sätt möjliggöra planering och genomförande av humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Framework agreement with Swedish Mission council (SMC). Mainly in Sudan and South Sudan and RRM + non allocated.

The overarching objective of SMC's Humanitarian Programme 2014-2016 is to "Save lives, alleviate suffering and increase resilience in affected communities whilst maintaining people’s dignity, through humanitarian assistance that ensures that women, men, girls, and boys receive support, including the most vulnerable groups."Each project funded under the programme has its own specific objectives, in terms of delivery of humanitarian assistance to people in need, contributing to the overall objective.

description.narrative: During the three year implementation period Sida has contributed a total of 96,3 million Swedish Kronor to support the Swedish Mission Council (SMC)'s humanitarian programme 2014-2016. The program comprises two components: 1. Establishment of the humanitarian team and building capacity for humanitarian assistance, within SMC and its member organizations. 2. Delivery of humanitarian assistance to people in need, through so called "Major Interventions" and shorter projects under a Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM-projects). 1. Establishment of the humanitarian team and building capacity for humanitarian assistance. Some of the main achievements under this component include: Set-up of a humanitarian team: The Humanitarian team has enabled SMC to channel humanitarian funding to partner organizations delivering humanitarian assistance to people in need, in several humantiarian crises around the world, through both Major Interventions and RRM-projects, and to perform continous monitoring and quality assurance of the projects funded. Enhanced access to the humanitarian system for local actors: SMC has collaborated with local churches and organizations through its networks and thus increased their access to the humanitarian financial system, therby contributing to the fullfillment of commitments in the Grand Bargain. Increased humanitarian access to hard-to-reach areas: SMC and its partners have achieived access to complex and highly insecure and/or politicized contexts and delivered humanitarian assistance to people who would otherwise not have access to aid. For instance, ADRA was able to access people in need in Bangladesh, Yemen and Uganda, fostering partnerships with other faith-based organizations. Incorporation of the Core Humanitarian Standard on Quality and Accountability (CHS) in SMC’s humanitarian team and implementing partners: SMC’s partner organizations have integrated the nine CHS commitments in their workstreams, as demonstrated e.g. in Ethiopia in 2016 under EMWACDO, where efforts were made to tailor CHS to the local culture and language, as well as to engage the community and district government actors in working with CHS. Improved capacity of local actors: SMC’s humanitarian partners have actively integrated a gender perspective. While this process has not yet reached its optimal level, SMC has successfully kickstarted the process of changing many church-based organizations’ patriarchal structures. Moreover, ERIKS – one of SMC’s partner organization - has incorporated a child protection perspective into its humanitarian assistance programs, tailoring e.g. nutrition and education-related activities to the specific needs of children. Stronger humanitarian-development nexus: While no concrete results were achieved in this area, SMC has initiated a dialogue on ways moving forwards in improving understanding about entry points to bridging humanitarian and development aid. 2. Delivery of humanitarian assistance Between 2014 and 2017, SMC and its partners have implemented 41 interventions to assist a total of more than 600,000 people in need. Aid modalitites and sectors include the provision of fresh water and assisting beneficiaries with trainings on hygiene and sanitation, food-distribution, protection and distribution of essential Non-Food-Items (NFIs) such mosquito nets, blankets, tarpaulins and kitchen utensils. Examples include: Bangladesh, where ADRA and Eriks, through two separate interventions in 2017, have provided emergency relief to flood affected communities and contributed to enhancing community resilience. Among other things, Eriks provided 10,400 flood victim families with food packages and installed 12 emergency tube wells, which gave 112 families access to safe drinking water. ADRA rehabilitated 12 community ponds benefitting 1,000 households who thereby gained access to safe drinking water. The organization also installed 37 sanitary latrines. Israel/Palestine. From 2014-2017, Sida supported the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel (EAPPI) through SMC and the Swedish Council of Churches, SCC. EAPPI’s overall objective is to decrease violations of human rights and international humanitarian law in Palestine and Israel through accompaniment and during the three year period the programme has, among other things, allowed Ecumenical Accompaniers (EA) to visit 288 communities (cities, villages, refugee-camps, Bedouin/herder communities) and provide protective presence at five major Israeli controlled checkpoints through which a total average of 27,500 persons cross daily. In addition 7,860 children and 396 teachers recieved protective presence in order to access and provide education. South Sudan. ADRA has increased access to safe water for 21,500 people in 28 communities in Northern Bahr el Ghazal, by drilling 12 new boreholes and rehabilitating 14 peviosly non-functional boreholes. Water committees were established and trained to manage and maintain each of the 26 boreholes. Similarly, IAS South Sudan provided critical WASH solutions to 30 conflict-affected communities of Western Equatoria, Jonglei and Unity states, benefitting 19,500 people. In Taiz, Yemen, ADRA provided food assistance to 9,000 people in line with World Food Programme standards, and safe water, hygiene and disease control to 1,220 households. The organization also reached 975 households with mine risk education messages, contributing to prevention of injury and death due to landmines and unexploded ordinance.
